Judge Timothy Kelly postponed until Thursday a decision on whether to at least temporarily restore Acosta’s press pass. But the arguments Wednesday represented a significant escalation in Trump’s fight against the media, with more than a dozen news organizations, including POLITICO, weighing in on CNN’s side.

Trump has long argued that coverage of his administration is unfair, and CNN has been a favorite target. Even before he took office, the president referred to Acosta as “fake news” at a press conference and refused to take questions from him. The White House also has substantially curtailed the number of briefings by press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders.

But reporters have retained access to the White House and traveled with the president, and before last week, revoking a journalist’s hard pass — the badge that lets them enter and exit the complex freely — was virtually unheard-of.

The White House said last Wednesday it was pulling Acosta’s access after he repeatedly tried to ask Trump questions at a press conference, even after the president dismissed him, and briefly refused to let a White House aide pull a microphone out of his hand. CNN on Tuesday asked a judge to temporarily restore Acosta's credentials and declare that the administration's actions were unconstitutional, saying Trump was punishing the network for its coverage of him and not for any action on Acosta’s part.

Ted Boutrous of Gibson and Dunn, who represented CNN and Acosta, said Wednesday that the White House’s decision was “part of a campaign” against Acosta, citing previous tweets and incidents in which Trump had insulted the reporter. He said under the White House’s logic, the president could bar reporters for any reason, including a “fit of pique.”

He also argued that Acosta, who was present for the hearing, was not afforded “due process” because he was not told his pass would be revoked beforehand or given a way to appeal the decision before he was prevented from entering White House grounds. He requested a two-week preliminary return of Acosta’s pass while the process moved forward.

A 1977 D.C. Circuit court ruling held that the government cannot deny a White House hard pass “arbitrarily or for less than compelling reasons” and must follow a clear process to do it. Kelly noted during the hearing that he would be bound by that court’s decision in issuing a ruling, and Boutrous cited the case repeatedly in his arguments.

Burnham, arguing for the White House, acknowledged that the administration had dropped its initial argument against Acosta: That he had inappropriately touched a White House aide who tried to take a microphone away from him at the press conference.

But he said Acosta’s behavior at the press conference still justified his expulsion, saying his repeated attempts to question the president after Trump tried to move on were “disruptive.” And in response to questions from Kelly, he said the administration would be justified in pulling a hard pass because of disputes over reporting, saying barring a reporter from a press conference was no different than refusing to grant them a private interview.

Burnham conceded that he did not know who in the administration made the actual decision to strip Acosta of his press pass — it was announced on Twitter by Sanders — and said it did not matter that there are no set-out or written standards governing reporter behavior in the White House. Boutros seized on those points to argue that Acosta was not afforded due process.

Kelly, a Trump appointee, seemed skeptical of some of CNN's arguments and appeared to agree that Acosta had been disruptive at the press conference. Boutrous responded that Trump set a tone of rudeness. “He is the most aggressive, dare I say rude, person in the room,” Boutros said. “[If] President Trump wants it to be a free-for-all, that’s his prerogative.”

The White House argued in its legal filing Wednesday that because it has granted hard passes to many other CNN employees, the network cannot say its coverage led to Acosta’s expulsion. The 28-page document mentioned six times that 50 CNN employees have hard passes. Boutrous pointed out that most of those employees are technicians and photographers, part of the large staff a TV network maintains to cover events live at the White House.

Reporters have denounced the decision to pull Acosta's access. Thirteen news organizations including Fox News, NBC and POLITICO announced Wednesday they would file amicus briefs supporting CNN's lawsuit.

"It is imperative that independent journalists have access to the President and his activities, and that journalists are not barred for arbitrary reasons. Our news organizations support the fundamental constitutional right to question this President, or any President," a joint statement from the news organizations said.

Meanwhile, on CNN, coverage appeared to be business-as-usual Wednesday.

CNN White House reporters Jeff Zeleny and Kaitlan Collins reported live from outside the White House on the latest West Wing personnel turmoil, neither of them mentioning the court hearing playing out across the town.

“In many ways, we’re compartmentalizing our coverage,” a CNN source told POLITICO. White House reporters will continue focusing on what’s happening at the White House, this person said, while other CNN journalists cover the lawsuit.

“The president of the United States is the most important person we cover,” the source added. “We will cover the president as we always have. We will cover him thoroughly. It’s business as usual as our coverage goes.”

A second CNN source said network president Jeff Zucker believes the press access fight is “an important story” but isn’t over-covering it as “he wants to be very careful not to weaponize the network.”

CNN appeared to focus more Wednesday on wildfires in California and post-midterms fallout in Washington than the lawsuit. But the network did turn to chief media correspondent Brian Stelter for updates and Jeffrey Toobin for analysis on the court proceedings.

White House officials, meanwhile, have largely been tight-lipped about the lawsuit, although Trump told the Daily Caller in an interview published Wednesday that Acosta was “bad for the country.”

And the president’s 2020 reelection campaign sent out a fundraising email asking recipients whether they think the White House made the right decision to revoke Acosta’s pass.

“President Trump will NOT put up with the media’s liberal bias and utter disrespect for this Administration and the hardworking Americans who stand with us,” the email read.

Matthew Choi contributed to this report.

Matthew Whitaker was previously chief of staff to now-ousted Attorney General Jeff Sessions — a job that didn’t require Senate confirmation. | Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images Legal DOJ defends Trump’s acting A.G. appointment in memo The 20-page DOJ memo leans heavily on historical precedent to argue that Trump was well within his constitutional and legal bounds.

A new Justice Department analysis released Wednesday backs up President Donald Trump’s appointment last week of acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker despite a growing political and legal backlash.

The 20-page DOJ memo — addressed to top White House attorney Emmet Flood — leans heavily on historical precedent to argue that Trump was well within his constitutional and legal bounds to elevate Whitaker over other senior Justice officials as the temporary replacement for ousted Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

Story Continued Below

Whitaker, a former federal prosecutor who was working as Sessions’ chief of staff before getting the promotion to become the nation’s top law enforcement official, has already drawn lawsuits and congressional scrutiny over his conflicts of interest and because he hasn’t been confirmed for any current Justice position.

But Steven Engel, the head of DOJ’s Office of Legal Counsel, argued in the new memo that the Justice Department has previously leaned on the same law Trump used — the Vacancies Reform Act — to depart from its own succession plans.

In addition, Engel pushed back against suggestions Trump violated the Constitution’s Appointments Clause by noting that someone who performs the duties in a temporary capacity doesn’t have to go through the Senate confirmation process.

“As all three branches of government have long recognized, the President may designate an acting official to perform the duties of a vacant principal office, including a Cabinet office, even when the acting official has not been confirmed by the Senate,” wrote Engel.

Drawing on U.S. history, Engel explained that presidents have had the legal right to put non-Senate confirmed officials into government positions going as far back as 1792. That includes more than 160 appointments before 1860 for positions that included secretaries of State, Treasury, War, Navy and Interior.

DOJ also found an example from 1866 when a non-Senate confirmed assistant attorney general took over as acting attorney general.

“Mr. Whitaker’s designation is no more constitutionally problematic than countless similar presidential orders dating back over 200 years,” Engel wrote.

While much of the Justice Department memo is devoted to the long history of similar appointments, the Supreme Court has sometimes scoffed at such arguments when the justices conclude that such practices fly in the face of the Constitution.

In 2012, the Justice Department issued a similar legal opinion justifying three of President Barack Obama's appointments to the National Labor Relations Board. And in 2014, the justices unanimously ruled those appointments unconstitutional. However, they appeared divided on how much deference to give to tradition in such disputes.

Complaints about Whitaker have only grown since Trump last week tapped Whitaker the day after the November mid-term elections where Democrats won control of the House. Already, the state of Maryland has filed a motion Tuesday in federal court seeking to overturn the Whitaker appointment. Incoming House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler has said Whitaker would be his first witness when Democrats take control of the lower chamber in January.

In promoting Whitaker, Trump has also sparked an uproar because of his past criticism of special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation examining any potential conspiracy between Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign and Russia.

Whitaker in his new role has taken over supervising duties of Mueller’s work from Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general who was in charge of the special counsel because Sessions had previously recused himself from the topic.

DOJ initially said Whitaker had no plans to back away from overseeing Mueller, but on Monday it signaled the acting attorney general was consulting with senior DOJ ethics officials and reopened the possibility he could recuse himself.

Josh Gerstein contributed to this report.

Sen. Joni Ernst's rise marks the first time in eight years a woman has joined the Senate GOP leadership. | Alex Wong/Getty Images Congress Ernst joins GOP Senate leadership Sens. Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer were also re-elected to lead their respective parties.

Sen. Joni Ernst of Iowa on Wednesday beat Nebraska's Deb Fischer to win the Republican Senate Conference vice chairmanship, the only contested leadership race in a Senate that will return the bulk of the parties' leaders.

Ernst's win over Fischer marks the first time in eight years a woman is in the Senate GOP leadership. Senators said they were not provided with a vote total, and Fischer quickly moved on and told reporters she's going to continue to be "very active" in the caucus' work. Ernst, who is up for reelection in 2020 and is expected to face a credible Democratic challenge, said she will focus on sharing the GOP's record of "prosperity" with her constituents while in Washington.

Story Continued Below

Sens. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) were reelected by voice vote to lead their respective parties, according to sources familiar with the decisions.

Several other significant but expected moves took place in the GOP caucus, mostly involving promotions for existing Senate leaders. Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.) will now be party whip, Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.) will be the conference chairman, the No. 3 job, and Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) will be the Republican Policy chairman. Senate President Pro Tempore Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) is retiring and will be replaced in the role by Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) as the most senior GOP senator and in the line of presidential succession.

And Sen. Todd Young (R-Ind.) will chair the National Republican Senatorial Committee for the next cycle, working to protect Ernst and outgoing NRSC Chairman Cory Gardner of Colorado, among other vulnerable senators. On the Democratic side, Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto (D-Nev.) has spoken to Schumer about chairing the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, but no final decision has been made, according to multiple Democratic sources.

McConnell's reelection makes him the GOP leader for his seventh term. Schumer will begin his second term as minority leader next year.

poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201811/2910/1155968404_5940956678001_5940956253001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404" true

No one opposed Schumer vocally, including Sen.-elect Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, who had said during her campaign she would not support Schumer, according to two senators. Those senators said they did not hear anyone object to Schumer’s nomination.

“Had there been a challenger for minority leader, I would have considered new leadership and a fresh perspective,” Sinema said in a statement. “I will continue to put Arizona over party.”

Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn of Texas, who is term-limited, is leaving the elected leadership but will still be a "counsel" to McConnell. Fischer is currently a counsel but said she was unsure whether she will stay in that role in the next Congress.

The sprawling Democratic leadership team does not have term limits like the GOP and will remain unchanged, other than at the DSCC position. The top rungs of the team will include: Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), Assistant Democratic Leader Patty Murray (D-Wash.) and Democratic Policy and Communications Committee Chairman Debbie Stabenow (D-Mich.). Other members of the leadership team are Sens. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Mark Warner (D-Va.), Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.), Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Tammy Baldwin (D-Wis.).

Marianne Levine contributed to this report.

Sen. Chris Coons (right), who sits on the Judiciary Committee with Sen. Jeff Flake, said he agreed with the retiring Arizona lawmaker about the unnecessary deployment of troops. | Alex Wong/Getty Images Immigration Flake, Coons call troop deployments to the border a 'stunt'

Sen. Jeff Flake on Wednesday called President Donald Trump's decision to deploy U.S. troops along the U.S.-Mexico border a "stunt," noting that the troops in his home state of Arizona had actually been deployed almost 100 miles from the border itself.

“I think it's unfortunate that we have soldiers there, and frankly in Arizona they are stationed in Tucson about 90 miles from the border. So they are not forward deployed actually on the border,” the outgoing Republican said on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.” “So I think you can't call it anything but a stunt here, and it's unfortunate that they are going to be away from family during the holidays coming up, and we just don't know what really for.”

Story Continued Below

Critics of the Trump administration have accused the president of using military resources as political chess pieces, along with heated rhetoric, in the lead-up to last week's midterm elections in an effort to stir concern over caravans of asylum-seeking migrants headed for the U.S. as a dangerous “invasion.”

Trump railed against the migrants repeatedly in the final days of the campaign, but has fallen mostly silent on the issue since Election Day, save for an executive order last week to block the migrants from seeking asylum if they are caught crossing the border illegally.

She is the first woman of color to hold an executive leadership role at the organization,. | John Minchillo/AP Photo Elections Democracy for America installs first female chief executive

The progressive political action committee Democracy for America is appointing its first female chief executive as it reorganizes ahead of the 2020 presidential campaign, while Jim Dean will step down from his role as chair.

Yvette Simpson, a former Cincinnati councilwoman, will become chief executive Jan. 1, the first woman of color to hold an executive leadership role at the organization, the group said.

Story Continued Below

The appointment represents a generational shift for DFA, as younger, nonwhite voters and candidates put their mark on progressive politics nationwide. DFA boasts more than 1 million members and was an instrumental supporter of Sen. Bernie Sanders’ failed 2016 presidential campaign.

“After an election year defined by historic firsts and the profound impact women of color played in delivering them, I couldn’t be more excited about Democracy for America’s future with Yvette Simpson as its new Chief Executive,” Dean said in a prepared statement. “Having the opportunity to work closely with the grassroots to help push our country in a more progressive direction has truly been an honor and one of the greatest thrills of my life, but I also know that we won’t be able to achieve the kind of change our country needs if we don’t let a new generation of bold, visionary progressive leaders, like Yvette, lead the way.”

Asked about criticism that progressive groups have failed to reflect diversity, Dean said, “I think this is an important step for us to move beyond that.”

BRADY'S READY: House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady isn't sure how much appetite his colleagues will have for tax legislation during the lame-duck session, but he's ready just in case. The Texas Republican is planning to soon circulate draft legislation to fix the "retail glitch" and other hiccups in the new tax law, along with a tax extenders package, our Aaron Lorenzo reports. It could be House Republicans' last tax hurrah before slipping into the minority next year.

Story Continued Below

Tax pros and those affected by the retail glitch have been waiting for months to see if Republicans would put forward a technical corrections bill for the tax law, H.R. 1 (115). Of course, retailers and restaurant owners consider their problem to be more than just technical. The glitch requires them to write off certain investments over decades, rather than over one year as Republicans intended. Brady said his legislation will include 70 to 80 other alterations to the law, the vast majority of which he characterized as very minor clarifications, Aaron wrote. "Again, we'll see what appetite there is to pass some or the bulk of them before the end of the year," Brady said.

The second piece of legislation includes a group of tax incentives with expiration dates that didn't make it into 2015 legislation that made dozens of other extenders permanent. "We have developed a draft package approach on the temporary measures that we're going to visit with our members about, Ranking Member [Richard] Neal and the Senate as well," Brady told reporters. He's been a longtime advocate of ending the annual extenders ritual, but it never seems to work out.

NOW IT CAN BE TOLD: The incentive packages that states, cities and counties were offering Amazon to host its second headquarters have been largely veiled in secrecy. But the company’s decision to split the HQ, and its 50,000 jobs, between Arlington’s Crystal City and Long Island City in Queens has pulled the veil back a bit. To wit: The state of New York will provide $1.2 billion in tax credits and a $325 million capital grant; the company also plans to apply for up to $1 billion in other incentives through NYC programs, POLITICO New York’s Dana Rubinstein reported. In Virginia, state and county officials will fork over $573 million in cash grants, the Technology team’s Steven Overly reported. Tennessee will provide a $21.7 million tax credit to offset franchise and excise taxes for an "Operations Center of Excellence" in Nashville, the company said in a blog post announcing the deals.

The tax incentive offered by New York will come in the form of a refundable tax credit "calculated as a percentage of the salaries Amazon expects to pay employees over the next 10 years, which equates to $48,000 per job for 25,000 jobs with an average wage of over $150,000," Amazon said. Arlington's cash grant will come from expected growth in revenue from its hotel room tax. The city will also "dedicate an estimated $28 million based on 12% of future property tax revenues earned from an existing Tax Increment Financing (TIF) district for on-site infrastructure and open space" in Crystal City, Amazon said. The company offered no explanation for the wide difference in incentives between the two cities, though it presumably has to do with higher taxes and other expenses in New York City.

While New York and Virginia officials hailed Amazon’s decision as an economic coup for their regions, naysayers came out of the woodwork. “The arrangements have drawn the ire of Amazon critics including incoming Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, whose district neighbors Long Island City,” Steven reported. “‘Amazon is a billion-dollar company,” she tweeted late Monday night. "’The idea that it will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at a time when our subway is crumbling and our communities need MORE investment, not less, is extremely concerning to residents here.’”

ACTING JUDICIOUSLY: Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) said he has to consult with his colleagues before deciding whether to take the gavel of the Finance Committee or stay on as Judiciary chairman. “Grassley has long said he would make his decision immediately after the midterms, presumably to see who captured the majority,” our Burgess Everett reported. “But now he says he needs more time to talk to GOP senators that will be affected by his decision given the domino effect Grassley will produce either way.” Grassley told reporters that he “forgot that I have an obligation” to see what his fellow Republican senators think.

Judiciary may offer more razzle-dazzle than Finance. “The Judiciary Committee is a contentious and difficult committee to lead, but it may have more sway than the Finance Committee in the next divided Congress given the lack of ideological overlap between the incoming House Democratic majority and the Senate GOP majority on tax policy,” Burgess wrote. “Senate Republicans can confirm judicial nominees with no support from Democrats, which could make that job more influential in the coming months.”

RETTIG NOT SO CRYPTIC: Newly minted IRS Commissioner Chuck Rettig has a message for virtual currency aficionados who try to game the tax system: We’re watching. “Given the agency’s ‘John Doe’ summons on the virtual currency exchange Coinbase, on which cryptocurrencies trade, the IRS has more information than many may imagine,” Rettig said in his first public comments since becoming commissioner last month, Aaron reports. “You think the IRS doesn’t know? You heard of Coinbase? Watch where we’re headed,” he said at the AICPA National Tax Conference. His comments seemed at least partly motivated by a demand from some House Ways and Means Republicans, including Brady, that the agency release updated guidance on how tax law applies to cryptocurrencies. The AICPA has made a similar request.

Rettig also promised a new level of cooperation between the IRS and tax practitioners, “saying they’re all in the business of tax compliance,” Aaron wrote. Toward that end of his speech, he said the agency would publicize internal training material on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act to give practitioners a better understanding of how it is implementing the law. “You’ll pick something up,” he told attendees at the AICPA gathering.

NEOMI, WE HARDLY NEW YE: The top regulator in the Trump administration, Neomi Rao, is the president’s pick to succeed Brett Kavanaugh on the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. Rao’s Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs recently won the power to review Treasury Department tax regulations under an agreement between Treasury and OMB, the parent agency of OIRA.

Rao may actually have more influence on regulations if she’s confirmed by the Senate. Regulatory challenges often end up on the D.C. court’s docket and, as our Alex Guillen reported, “Rao has run Trump’s deregulatory agenda across the federal government.” She’s also a critic of the Chevron doctrine, which generally holds that agencies will get the benefit of the doubt in court cases involving ambiguous laws. The doctrine has played a role in numerous tax cases since the Supreme Court ruled in 2011 that it applies to Treasury regulations. In congressional testimony in 2016, when she was a law professor at George Mason University, Rao said Chevron “has allowed for the expansion of the administrative state outside the checks and balances of the Constitution,” Alex wrote.

AMAZON’S DOUBLE-EDGED SWORD: In Northern Virginia and New York, Amazon’s plans to build new headquarters facilities are being described as either a golden opportunity to improve transportation infrastructure or an added burden to already overloaded systems. In Virginia, state and city governments are pledging more than half a billion dollars in transportation investments, including improvements to metro stations, a new pedestrian bridge and upgrades to Route 1, according to The Washington Post. WHAT TO EXPECT: President Donald Trump and senior officials have been discussing how to approach China as a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping approaches. European Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström meets with U.S. Trade Representative Robert LIghthizer today and hopes Trump keeps his promise of keeping auto tariffs at bay. The U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission wants the U.S. to step up its fight against China at the WTO. Start here:

THE WINDING ROAD TO THE G-20: Trump’s strategy ahead of a high-stakes meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping is about as clear as mud, but there has been some work behind the scenes. Trump met last Thursday with his envoy to Beijing, Terry Branstad, as well as Lighthizer, Secretary of State Michael Pompeo and chief of staff John Kelly. The meeting was supposed to map out the best way to talk to China about national security and trade, said a source briefed on the meeting.

The White House wants to “push the Chinese to where they need to get in order to make a deal,” the source said about the upcoming meeting, and thinks China is ready to do that now that Republicans showed they could maintain control of the Senate.

The Mnuchin angle: It’s still unclear what Trump wants to get out of Xi during the face-to-face, but China watchers say they are wary of news that Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin could meet in the coming weeks with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He ahead of the G-20 meeting. As of Friday, USTR had not been involved in the planning of that meeting, said one source familiar with the planning. Even at Treasury, staff-level China experts haven’t been involved in planning for a potential meeting or preparation for the G-20 get together, according to two sources close to the process.

“If USTR is not involved, then we have the same problem as before,” said one of the sources, referring to a failed effort to reach a deal in May that was led by Mnuchin. Hardliners fear that another effort with Mnuchin at the helm could lead to an outcome that doesn’t pressure Beijing to address substantive issues related to China’s intellectual property and technology transfer policies.

COFFEE AND CONVERSATION — The Pro Canada team and POLITICO Senior Politics Editor Charlie Mahtesian are joining the Nelson Mullins law firm for a breakfast briefing Thursday on the implications of the midterm elections for U.S.-Canada relations. Kicking things off will be Nelson Mullins partner and former U.S. Ambassador to Canada David Wilkins. Get the details and sign up.

KUDLOW UNLEASHES ON NAVARRO’S CHINA COMMENTS: As if we weren’t confused enough about what message the administration is trying to send to China ahead of the meeting between Trump and Xi, National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow said White House trade adviser Peter Navarro did the president a “great disservice” in his remarks last Friday.

“He was not speaking for the president, nor was he speaking for the administration. His remarks were way off base. They were not authorized by anybody,” Kudlow said on CNBC on Tuesday.

Navarro had said there would be a “stench” around any deal that involves the influence of Goldman Sachs and other Wall Street players. Kudlow said the president “can talk to whomever he can talk to. He talks to people on Wall Street, yes.”

Kudlow added that “we’re having communications at all levels of U.S. and Chinese government.”

Koch groups weigh in on G-20: The Koch network of free trade groups are urging Trump and Xi to end the trade war between the world’s two largest economies. In a letter released this morning, Americans for Prosperity, Freedom Partners and The Libre Initiative called for dropping the tariffs, which they say have hurt the global economy.

NO CAR TARIFFS YET; MALMSTRÖM STILL EXPECTS EU REPRIEVE: The Commerce Department is still working on its report on whether imports of autos and auto part imports threaten national security, according to a senior administration official — but when it recommends tariffs as expected, European Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström wants the U.S. to keep its promise to spare the EU.

“We assume if that were to happen, that would not be for the European Union,” Malmström said Tuesday in remarks at the German Marshall Fund.

Commerce’s Section 232 investigation could allow Trump to impose 20 percent or 25 percent duties on auto and auto part imports.

Malmström is halfway through a two-day trip to the United States to discuss the parameters of future negotiations. Malmström will meet with Lighthizer today. Doug has more here.

CHINA COMMISSION URGES NEW FIGHT AT WTO: The U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission is encouraging Congress to step up the fight against China’s trade practices in its annual report to Congress today.

Top among 26 recommendations is that lawmakers urge the administration to pursue a rarely invoked “non-violation nullification or impairment" case against Beijing at the WTO. That type of case would allow countries to challenge China for economic practices that don’t violate specific WTO rules but prevent Beijing from meeting its obligation to maintain a open and market-oriented economy.

“It’s quite clear [President Xi Jinping] and the Chinese communist party have taken control of the economy and not necessarily in the most healthy or productive way,” commission Chairwoman Robin Cleveland told reporters Tuesday. Read the full story here.

HOW THE CHINA TRADE FIGHT COULD GET EVEN WORSE: Consumers have not yet felt a major hit from Trump’s trade battle with China, but that could change later this year if the countries cannot make a deal. In the latest POLITICO Money podcast, our Doug Palmer explains the potential for Trump to hit more than $500 billion in Chinese imports with tariffs as high as 25 percent over the coming months.

U.S. COUNTER-NOTIFIES AT THE WTO: The U.S. called out India at the WTO for underreporting the extent of its market price support for cotton. The move, known as a “counter notification,” is part of a broader effort by the U.S. to pressure WTO members to fully disclose subsidies and other domestic measures that affect trade. The U.S. calculated that India’s cotton support program exceeded its allowable threshold for trade-distorting domestic support.

FRUSTRATION MOUNTS OVER TARIFF EXCLUSION ‘MESS’: The Commerce Department’s tariff exclusion process was meant to ease the burden on U.S. companies that rely on imports, but the Aluminum Association is arguing that even after proposed reforms, the complicated operation is only making things worse.

"The inherent uncertainty of the product exclusion process is actually adding an unnecessarily prolonged cost burden to our members and their customers and chilling investment in the aluminum industry, rather than promoting domestic production," the group said in a letter sent Tuesday to Commerce Department officials.

Lauren Wilk, vice president for policy at the Aluminum Association, added in an interview: “It’s kind of a mess.” Doug has more for Pros here.

TRADE STAFF SWITCH-UP AT FINANCE: Nasim Fussell will take over as chief international trade counsel for Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee. She was previously deputy chief trade counsel on the committee. Shane Warren, who fills the top trade staffer position, will be leaving after five years on the panel, a Finance spokeswoman told Morning Trade.

Fussell joined the committee earlier this year after working as director of government and regulatory affairs at Pitney Bowes, a mailing equipment and services company. She also served as a trade counsel on the House Ways and Means Committee, working under the chairmanships of Dave Camp (R-Mich.), Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and Kevin Brady (R-Texas). During her time on the House panel, she worked to advance trade promotion authority, customs, trade preferences and miscellaneous tariff bill legislation.

Chairman question mark: Sen. Chuck Grassley is still on the short list of lawmakers who could take the Finance chairmanship when Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) leaves Congress after this term. But the Iowa Republican said he needs more time to discuss the possible move with his colleagues. To take the top spot on Finance, Grassley would have to give up the gavel to the Judiciary Committee.

“You ask me that in a few days and I’ll have an answer for you,” Grassley told reporters on Tuesday. POLITICO’s Burgess Everett has more here on the committee scene in next year’s Senate.

AFTER TARIFFS, SPANISH OLIVE IMPORTS DROP 72 PERCENT: Imports of Spanish table olives to the U.S. dropped by nearly three-quarters in August and September, the first two months after anti-subsidy and anti-dumping duties went into effect, the Spanish olive farmers association ASAMESA said Tuesday.

Following a complaint from Californian olive producers, which claimed their Spanish competitors benefited from unfair subsidies, Washington in July imposed hefty tariffs ranging from 30 percent to 45 percent on Spanish table olives. Madrid and the European Commission strongly reject the justification for those duties.

Brussels still in talks: The European Commission said Tuesday it continues to raise the issue with U.S. authorities — including during Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross’ visit to Brussels last month — but has not yet decided whether it would launch a WTO case.

WHAT’S HAPPENING TODAY: Today will be another busy day in Washington — headlined by a hearing on the VA’s EHR implementation progress:

— VA hearing may probe lack of light from “Lighthouse”: The House Veterans Affairs’ tech modernization subcommittee will grill the chief of the Cerner EHR implementation, John Windom, at a hearing today. “People do a lot for savings. People do a lot of things to save money,” he said. Pros can get the rest here.

— Alphabet re-orgs health work: Alphabet is reshuffling the org chart for its health care companies, CNBC’s Christina Farr reports. SCARED OFF FOOD STAMPS?: As the Trump administration readies a final regulation that would make it harder for immigrants who’ve received food stamps or other government benefits to secure a green card, a new study by Boston Medical Center’s Children’s HealthWatch reports that participation by eligible immigrant families in the food-stamp program fell nearly 10 percentage points during the first half of 2018.

This finding, which came from surveying more than 35,000 mothers of children four years and younger in Boston, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Minneapolis, and Little Rock, reverses a ten-year trend. Participation in the food stamp program by eligible immigrant families rose to 43 percent in 2007-2017 before declining in 2018 to 34.8 percent. Heated immigration rhetoric and increased enforcement and detention are “a likely reason for many people dropping out,” Allison Bovell-Ammon, lead researcher on the study, told Evich (though she conceded that “it could also be because the economy is improving.”) Ellen Vollinger, legal/SNAP director at the Food Research & Action Center, a D.C. nonprofit, said: “I think this data really does confirm these anecdotes we've been hearing.” More from POLITICO’s Helena Bottemiller Evich here.

USW RATIFIES U.S. STEEL CONTRACT: The United Steelworkers union yesterday voted to ratify a new contract with U.S. Steel, concluding a battle over the sharing of windfall profits from President Donald Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs. The contract includes a 14 percent pay increase over four years and increases retirement benefits for 16,000 workers, according to the union.

“In 2015, workers recognized that the steel industry was struggling and agreed to make sacrifices so that U.S. Steel could get through some tough times,” United Steelworkers President Leo Gerard said in a statement. "Now that the company has recovered and is projected to earn nearly $2 billion this year, workers rightly wanted a share of that success."

The raise doesn’t come close to absorbing the bulk of new profits reported by U.S. Steel. This month, the company reported third-quarter earnings double those in 2017 — $291 million compared to $147 million, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported.

USW this month reached a tentative agreement with ArcelorMittal, which together with U.S. Steel accounts for 40 percent of the country's flat-rolled steel production. Members have yet to ratify that contract.

With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and Christian Vasquez

THE CYBER EAGLE HAS LANDED — A federal advisory committee is meeting today to approve a report urging President Donald Trump to create a “cybersecurity moonshot” project, modeled somewhat on the Apollo program, with the goal of securing the internet by 2028. “Because we took a moonshot approach of going out 10 years, we were able to open up our view and look laterally, and not just look at new technologies or advances in technology or existing technology,” Peter Altabef, who co-chaired the group that prepared the report, told Eric. There has been no shortage of reports urging massive changes to the internet ecosystem, but Altabef said the cyber moonshot was “fundamentally different.”

One thing that distinguishes the moonshot, according to Altabef, is its focus on interdependencies in networked technology. “I don’t think that has been done before,” he said. “Most cybersecurity efforts are near-term, interim, and relatively piecemeal.” He also argued that the report’s tight recommended timeframe would spur action. “This is a 10-year effort, but it is also a six-month effort and a one-year effort,” he said. “So there’s urgency to this. It is not all ‘wake up in 10 years and it’s fixed.’ We expect significant things to be happening during this process.”

The moonshot report is the product of more than a year of effort by a subcommittee of the National Security Telecommunications Advisory Committee, whose members have kept in close touch with officials at DHS and other agencies. “We are working in this effort with various parts of the administration very, very well,” Altabef said, describing officials as “very supportive.”

“We’re kind of at a watershed moment,” said Altabef, who argued that the U.S. had to yet experience a “Sputnik moment” in cybersecurity. “We can wait for that to occur,” he said, “or we can start something like this and try to head that off. … That becomes a whole-of-nation effort.”

THE FOUR HORSEMEN — In fall 2008, a U.S. service member stuck an infected USB flash drive into a laptop and set off a chain of events that would lead to the creation of U.S. Cyber Command. Now, as the president unshackles the organization, the architects of the newest U.S. military command offer rare insights into its origins and mission.

A decade ago, the U.S. military was just beginning to confront the risk of digital espionage and cyber warfare. “What [Defense Secretary Robert Gates] came up with and we discussed was, how do you better defend? Why do we have the offense and the defense in separate teams? Why don’t you put those together?” former NSA chief Keith Alexander told Martin. “If you’re going to set up a new command, you need to do all the planning for that. How do you get the right folks to do that?”

They became known as “the Four Horsemen,” a brain trust tasked with hammering out the plan to build the country’s first cyber warfare command and explaining it to a skeptical Washington. Today, Trump has formally elevated its status and made it the Defense Department’s newest “unified combatant command,” only the 10th of its kind. The promotion was followed a series of policy moves by the White House that, taken together, show a willingness to act first and ask questions later in the digital domain. “Our hands are not tied as they were in the Obama administration,” national security adviser John Bolton said in September. “We’re going to do a lot of things offensively, and our adversaries need to know that,” he added. CISA’S ON ITS WAY — The House on Tuesday evening sent a bill (H.R. 3359) to Trump reorganizing DHS’s main cyber division into the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Protection Agency. Nielsen, Ratcliffe and others applauded the House for clearing the legislation. The measure, which Trump is expected to sign given that every leading DHS official and even Vice President Mike Pence lobbied for it, will “bolster public-private partnerships to help ensure businesses have the resources and support necessary before, during, and after a cyber incident,” said Christopher Roberti, the senior vice president for cyber, intelligence and security policy at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

OPM STILL WEAK ON CYBER — The Office of Personnel Management still has a ways to go to secure its data, according to a Government Accountability Office report released Tuesday. Nearly a third of the 80 recommendations by the GAO after the 2015 breach have not been implemented, leaving the agency that maintains personal data on millions of current and former federal workers “at increased risk of unauthorized access, use, disclosure, modification, or disruption,” the report concluded. However, OPM plans to implement most of the remaining recommendations by the end of fiscal year 2018.

OPM’s security problems are nothing new. A security audit in late October from OPM’s Office of the Inspector General mirrors GAO’s concerns. The audit found that IT operations are “inappropriately decentralized” and that while procedures and policies are documented, they are not consistently implemented.

IN THEIR DEFENSE, IT’S ONLY BEEN THREE YEARS — The Pentagon hasn’t fully implemented all its requirements under the 2015 cybersecurity information sharing law, according to an inspector general report out Tuesday. The biggest barrier, the IG found, is that DoD’s chief information officer didn’t issue a policy on implementing the law. “As a result, the DoD limited its ability to gain a more complete understanding of cybersecurity threats since it did not fully leverage the collective knowledge and capabilities of sharing entities, or disseminate internally generated cyber threat indicators and defensive measures with other Federal and non‑Federal entities,” the report found. There were also problems with sub-agencies implementing the law and verifying security clearances.

IN THE HOPPER: New data from health researchers shows that immigrants are dropping out of SNAP over fears about the Trump administration’s immigration policies, as Pro Ag reported earlier this year. Participation among eligible immigrant households was down about 10 percentage points over the first half of 2018.

— ERS, NIFA relocation watch: Critics of USDA’s plans to relocate two research agencies out of D.C. next year are calling for a special provision in an upcoming spending bill to put the moves on hold.

— The oyster industry is dealing with severe shortages in the Gulf of Mexico. Alabama called off its oyster harvesting season, Gulf states are using oil spill settlement funds to rebuild oyster habitats, and the Supreme Court is even weighing in.

IMMIGRANT FAMILIES DROP FROM SNAP: Remember all those anecdotal reports about immigrants dropping out of SNAP over fears about the current administration’s immigration policies and rhetoric? They may be indicative of a larger national trend, according to preliminary data released this week.

Drop off: Immigrant households legally eligible for food-stamp benefits stopped participating in the program at a higher-than-normal rate in the first half of this year, the data show.

First dive: The data is the first broad look at Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program participation declines among immigrants, surveying more than 35,000 mothers across five U.S. cities. It found that participation dropped by nearly 10 percentage points in the first half of 2018 for immigrant households that are eligible for the program and have been in the U.S. less than five years — compared with a participation rate of 43 percent from 2007 to 2017.

— The study seems to confirm months of anecdotal reports, from New York to San Antonio, Texas, that widespread fear in immigrant communities has had a chilling effect on participation in SNAP and other government aid programs like WIC, a federal nutrition program aimed at pregnant women and children.

— “We were hearing the anecdotal reports of people dropping out of SNAP and WIC, so we started looking at our data to see if that was true among the families we interview,” said Allison Bovell-Ammon, lead researcher and deputy director for policy strategy at Boston Medical Center’s Children’s HealthWatch, which conducted the study. OYSTER SHORTAGES IN THE GULF: The oyster industry is facing severe shortages in the Gulf of Mexico, according to a report released today from The Nature Conservancy, a nonprofit group. The oyster population has declined by about 85 percent in the Gulf region, which leads the nation in commercial production.

The situation has become so grave that Alabama for the first time called off its oyster harvesting season due to scarcity. Officials are under pressure to balance protecting oysters as a commodity and as part of a habitat — the shellfish are integral to the survival of other marine wildlife.

“It’s only getting worse,” said Seth Blitch, the Nature Conservancy’s director of coastal and marine conservation in Louisiana. “These states are faced with trying to maintain stocks so there is a commercial harvest while trying to maintain natural resources, too.”

Where have all the oysters gone? The shortages, researchers say, aren’t so much about water quality as they are about water quantity. Imbalances of freshwater caused by droughts, hurricanes and other factors have decimated ecosystems and harvests.

The fight over freshwater access for oysters has even made its way to the Supreme Court — Florida and Georgia have been locked in a decadeslong battle over water access. In June, a divided court gave the Sunshine State another chance to prove Georgia was harming its oyster habitat by consuming too much water from the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River basin.

— The case, which has been sent back to a court-appointed special master for a final decision, could foreshadow how courts will play a role juggling water usage between humans and wildlife.

How to rebuild: States are tapping into their funds from the 2010 BP oil spill settlement reserved solely for oyster restoration. Texas, for example, announced today that it’s using $5 million of those funds to build an artificial reef that can be used for both restoration and harvesting.

TRADE MEETINGS ON DECK: U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström will meet today in D.C. to continue laying the groundwork ahead of formal bilateral negotiations starting as soon as mid-January.

European nations are considering ramping up their purchases of U.S. biofuel ingredients like rapeseed, our POLITICO Pro Europe colleagues reported this week — a potential olive branch for American farmers that might help the EU keep broader agricultural issues out of the upcoming trade talks.

But President Donald Trump wasn’t exactly feeling the love Tuesday morning, when he targeted France with a tweetstorm including a gripe about French wine tariffs. He’s set to meet with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker at the G-20 gathering this month in Buenos Aires.

Main event: He’ll also join Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G-20 for a highly anticipated face-to-face discussion on trade (and other issues). Our colleagues on the POLITICO White House team tell MA that U.S. Ambassador to China Terry Branstad met with Trump in D.C. last Thursday to go over plans for the meeting with Xi. (Lighthizer, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and White House chief of staff John Kelly were also there.)

Listen up: Pro Trade’s Doug Palmer joins the POLITICO Money podcast to explain how the trade feud with China could go from bad to worse, and fast. Plug in your headphones and check it out here.

ROW CROPS

— Denham defeated in House race: House Ag member Jeff Denham(R-Calif.) was defeated by Democrat Josh Harder in the Central Valley district. Denham’s loss comes despite a late campaign boost from Trump, who delivered Republicans in the farmland region a major win on all-important water policy. Here’s more on the final result.

— Anti-pesticide groups oppose Hutchins’ nomination: More than 245 groups against the broad use of pesticides are opposing Scott Hutchins’ nomination as USDA chief scientist because they say his ties to Corteva Agriscience, a division of DowDuPont, “present serious conflicts of interest that will undoubtedly affect his ability” to serve in the role if confirmed by the Senate. You can find the letter here.

— Atrazine levels widespread in corn belt water sources: The Environmental Working Group today released a new analysis of drinking water contaminated by the weedkiller atrazine in corn-growing regions. EWG found that potentially harmful levels of the herbicide have been detected in drinking water for nearly 30 million Americans across 28 states. The group previously released a tap water quality database as part of its efforts to raise attention about agriculture’s impact on water quality in rural areas.

— Immigrant ag workers still reeling from Hurricane Florence: Undocumented laborers in North Carolina, fearing possible deportation, have avoided seeking disaster assistance after the storm caused severe flooding in the state’s major pork producing regions. Civil Eats has the story.

— Cotton sector to adopt sustainability metrics: Cotton Council International this week announced plans for an integrated data collection, measurement and verification process that will track the environmental impact of U.S. cotton production to help ensure the industry is meeting its 2025 sustainability goals. The details of the U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol are still being finalized, but a pilot project will launch in 2019 and full implementation is expected for the 2020 crop year. Read more here.

— Green group partners with corn growers: The National Corn Growers Association and Environmental Defense Fund in a new partnership being announced today plan to focus on metrics to track progress on practices designed to improve water quality, soil health and reduce greenhouse gas emissions on American farms, while promoting profitability. Beyond data collection, the two groups also will work together on advocating for voluntary conservation programs with measurable outcomes.

— An orange forecast: Over the next three years, Florida orange production is expected to drop as old groves are replaced and new ones start to bear fruit — continuing a steady decline over the last two decades largely due to citrus greening disease, according to a new report by CoBank, a top lender to rural agribusinesses, cooperatives and utilities. Imports of orange juice from Brazil are on track to increase to meet U.S. demand.

— How dicamba drift came to be: Reveal from the Center for Investigative Reporting and the Food & Environment Reporting Network did a deep dive on the history of dicamba and EPA’s recent decision to reauthorize the controversial pesticide for two years, despite some scientists warning of continued unintended damage to crops.

The former Department of Homeland Security official under consideration to be its next secretary offered a defense on Wednesday morning of the woman he could succeed, Kirstjen Nielsen, and did not let on whether the president had approached him about the job.

Tom Homan, the former acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, told Fox News that “I won't speculate what the president will do,” but praised Nielsen as a “strong secretary” and said she was succeeding in a difficult job. Homan did allow that the president could let her go at any time he likes.

Story Continued Below

“It’s a 24/7/365 job,” Homan said. “Fifty percent of America hates you 100 percent of the time, you can't win on this topic because it is so divisive.”

POLITICO reported Tuesday that Homan, who is now a contributor at Fox News, won Trump’s affection as a tough talking immigration hard-liner in his interim role at ICE and with his cable news defenses of Trump’s border policies. Homan said earlier this year that he delayed his retirement as acting director on Trump's request.

Homan is being considered for the role along with U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Kevin McAleenan, TSA Administrator David Pekoske, and Maj. Gen. Vincent Coglianese, who currently runs the Marine Corps Installations Command.

Broward County, which emerged as the epicenter of controversy as three statewide races and three local legislative races went into recounts following the Nov. 6 elections, was one of the counties mentioned in affidavits released Tuesday. | AP Photo/Brynn Anderson Federal prosecutors reviewing altered election documents tied to Florida Democrats

TALLAHASSEE — The Florida Department of State last week asked federal prosecutors to investigate dates that were changed on official state election documents, the first voting “irregularities” it has flagged in the wake of the 2018 elections.

The concerns, which the department says can be tied to the Florida Democratic Party, center around date changes on forms used to fix vote-by-mail ballots sent with incorrect or missing information. Known as “cure affidavits,” those documents used to fix mail ballots were due no later than 5 p.m. on Nov. 5 — the day before the election. But affidavits released on Tuesday by the DOS show that documents from four different counties said the ballots could be returned by 5 p.m. on Thursday, which is not accurate.

Story Continued Below

Audio of a Florida Democratic Party caller leaving a voicemail message asking a Palm Beach County voter to fix their vote by mail ballot after Election Day, which is not allowed, was also sent to POLITICO separately. It was not part of the information turned over to federal prosecutors.

Among the counties in question is Broward, which emerged as the epicenter of controversy as three statewide races and three local legislative races went into recounts following the Nov. 6 elections. Republicans have pointed to embattled Broward Elections chief Brenda Snipes' record of past election gaffes in arguing that the largely Democratic country is tilted against them — perhaps fraudulently so.

DOS officials have repeatedly told the media that the monitors they sent to Broward County saw no election fraud. It wasn't until Tuesday that the office revealed publicly that it had turned over information to federal prosecutors.

The information was sent on Nov. 9 by Bradley McVay, DOS’ interim general counsel, who asked that the altered dates be investigated.

“Altering a form in a manner that provides the incorrect date for a voter to cure a defect … imposes a burden on the voter significant enough to frustrate the voter’s ability to vote,” McVay wrote in a letter that was sent Nov. 9 and released publicly on Tuesday. The letter was sent to U.S. Attorneys Christopher P. Canova of the Northern District of Florida, Maria Chapa Lopez of the Middle District of Florida and Ariana Fajardo Orshan in the Southern District of Florida.

The records released by DOS, which is part of Gov. Rick Scott’s administration, point the finger at the Florida Democratic Party. Political parties can get daily lists of people who had their mail-in ballots rejected. Political parties — or anyone else — can also get the publicly available cure affidavits and send them to voters who had a mail-in ballot rejected to encourage them to fix the ballots.

In an email chain released as part of the Department of State's Tuesday document dump, Citrus County Supervisor of Elections Susan Gill last week told DOS officials that a voter who received one of the cure affidavits with the wrong date had also received a call from a number identified as the Tallahassee office of the Florida Democratic Party, an indication the party was reaching out about her vote by mail ballot.

"When I called it, it is the Democratic Party of Florida," she said in a Nov. 8 email to DOS officials.

She went on to write that she thinks the incorrect date was used because whoever sent the cure affidavit mixed up the deadline for cure affidavits with the deadline for provisional ballots. But, she said, "a bigger problem is the fact they actually changed one of the DOE forms."

That change to an official election form was what state officials turned over to federal prosecutors.

Another email included in the DOS document dump included correspondence from Okaloosa County Supervisor of Elections Paul Lux, who also said he believed the affidavits were from the Florida Democratic Party.

"Please pass the word to the FDP that they can't arbitrarily add their own deadline to your form or VBM cures!!" Lux emailed DOS officials on Nov. 9. "This is crazy!"

In a Tuesday interview with POLITICO, Lux said he received an email from someone sending a cure affidavit marked with the wrong date that included a Florida Democratic Party email address. The email does contain the email address votes@FloridaDems.org, which is associated with the party.

Caroline Rowland, an FDP spokesperson, brushed off the issue, saying the Scott administration’s election office was drumming it up as a distraction.

"The courts have already forced Rick Scott to drop a lawsuit after false claims of fraud, and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement rejected his desperate attempts to interfere with the important work of counting ballots,” she said in an email. “Now, Scott is once again trying to divert attention and resources from a smooth and successful recount."

The records released by DOS, which is part of Gov. Rick Scott’s administration, point the finger at the Florida Democratic Party. Political parties can get daily lists of people who had their mail-in ballots rejected. Political parties — or anyone else — can also get the publicly available cure affidavits and send them to voters who had a mail-in ballot rejected to encourage them to fix the ballots.

In an email chain released as part of the Department of State's Tuesday document dump, Citrus County Supervisor of Elections Susan Gill last week told DOS officials that a voter who received one of the cure affidavits with the wrong date had also received a call from a number identified as the Tallahassee office of the Florida Democratic Party, an indication the party was reaching out about her vote by mail ballot.

"When I called it, it is the Democratic Party of Florida," she said in a Nov. 8 email to DOS officials.

She went on to write that she thinks the incorrect date was used because whoever sent the cure affidavit mixed up the deadline for cure affidavits with the deadline for provisional ballots. But, she said, "a bigger problem is the fact they actually changed one of the DOE forms."

That change to an official election form was what state officials turned over to federal prosecutors.

Another email included in the DOS document dump included correspondence from Okaloosa County Supervisor of Elections Paul Lux, who also said he believed the affidavits were from the Florida Democratic Party.

"Please pass the word to the FDP that they can't arbitrarily add their own deadline to your form or VBM cures!!" Lux emailed DOS officials on Nov. 9. "This is crazy!"

In a Tuesday interview with POLITICO, Lux said he received an email from someone sending a cure affidavit marked with the wrong date that included a Florida Democratic Party email address. The email does contain the email address votes@FloridaDems.org, which is associated with the party.

Caroline Rowland, an FDP spokesperson, brushed off the issue, saying the Scott administration’s election office was drumming it up as a distraction.

"The courts have already forced Rick Scott to drop a lawsuit after false claims of fraud, and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement rejected his desperate attempts to interfere with the important work of counting ballots,” she said in an email. “Now, Scott is once again trying to divert attention and resources from a smooth and successful recount."

KUDLOW VS NAVARRO BLOWS UP — Until now, NEC Director Larry Kudlow has approached the perennial free traders vs. nationalists fight inside the White House very differently than his predecessor Gary Cohn. Cohn, known for years as a Wall Street tough guy, regularly displayed his disdain for protectionist trade adviser Peter Navarro, moving to reduce Navarro’s role and keeping him out of meetings. Kudlow, genteel and gregarious by nature, has tried to stay on good terms with Navarro and keep policy disputes civil and inside the building.

Story Continued Below

That changed on Tuesday with Kudlow publicly rebuking Navarro during a CNBC interview over Navarro’s deeply hawkish China speech on Friday. The vibe coming out of the White House — partly in response to market declines — has been that progress is being made with China and that the G-20 meeting could pave the way for a deal. Navarro stomped all over that. And Kudlow was unhappy.

And he spoke in ways that had to have approval from the president. Kudlow and Trump kibitz regularly in person and by phone and it’s very difficult to imagine that the NEC director spoke this way about Navarro without approval from the president. This matters because among the most consequential economic decisions facing the White House right now is whether to enter into a full-blown trade war with China.

Here’s what Kudlow said: “Look, Peter Navarro is a friend of mine, truly. We’ve known each other for 20 years, but he was not speaking for the president, nor was he speaking for the administration. His remarks were way off base. They were not authorized by anybody. I actually think he did the president a great disservice. Look, the president can talk to whomever he can talk to. He talks to people on Wall Street, yes. He talks to union leaders.

“I’ve been in some of those meetings. He talks to other outside advisers. He has every right to do so. And the president has said … that if there is a deal to be had with China, it’s a deal that has to be in American interests. So I think Peter very badly misspoke. He was freelancing and he’s not representing the president or the administration.”

WIN FOR THE FREE TRADERS (FOR NOW) — The White House meeting on Tuesday on auto tariffs concluded with an agreement not to move forward with the levies for now, according to a person familiar with the meeting. The Commerce Department will continue to work on a report about whether imported autos impact national security. Trump has been hot to slap the tariffs on for quite a while but the auto industry doesn’t want them. And markets don’t want them. And they would presumably complicate negotiations with the EU barring a blanket exemption. For now they will remain a threat in Trump’s back pocket.

CRUNCH TIME ON TRADE — In the latest POLITICO Money podcast, POLITICO senior trade reporter Doug Palmer explains the potential for Trump to hit over $500 billion in Chinese imports with tariffs as high as 25 percent over the coming months. Consumers would feel such tariffs immediately and quite painfully.

Trump is scheduled to sit down with Chinese premier Xi Jinping at the Group of 20 Summit at the end of the month in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Free traders inside the administration are hoping the bilateral talks forestall another round of tariffs and set up future negotiations.

But there is a raging battle going on inside the West Wing with Navarro trying to tamp down hopes for the talks and free-trade voices including Kudlow sounding hopeful. The fear among the free traders is that another big round of tariffs will drive up consumer prices, further impede American exporters – especially farmers – and slow down economic growth. Higher prices caused by tariffs could also push the Federal Reserve into more aggressive interest rate hikes to fight inflation.

“Politicians, not surprisingly, are reluctant to change a system that they’re comfortable with,” said John Opdycke, president of Open Primaries. | Karen Matthews/AP Photo Legal Activist group sues to force open primaries

Proponents of open primaries are mounting a new line of attack in their effort to weaken political parties’ grip on American elections.

The New York-based Open Primaries Education Fund, representing four voters in New Mexico, said it filed a lawsuit Tuesday arguing closed primaries — primary elections that limit participation to registered party members — constitute an illegal gift of public funds. Such primaries, they claim, benefit political parties while disenfranchising independent voters.

Story Continued Below

The lawsuit hinges on a specific “anti-donation” clause of the New Mexico constitution. But supporters say the case, if successful, could have ramifications beyond New Mexico, serving as leverage to pressure lawmakers in other closed primary states.

“Politicians, not surprisingly, are reluctant to change a system that they’re comfortable with,” said John Opdycke, president of Open Primaries. “By raising the basic premise that publicly funded elections should be open to everybody, I think can really help both in the courts, but also in legislatures, to create more momentum.”

The issue rose to national prominence in 2016, when Bernie Sanders railed against closed primaries as an anti-democratic practice during his unsuccessful run for the Democratic presidential nomination. As he campaigned in the New York — a state with a closed primary —Sanders argued that the practice was “wrong.”

“Three million people in the state of New York who are independents have lost their right to vote in the Democratic or Republican primary,” said Sanders, who tended to perform better in open primary states where independent voters could vote for him in the Democratic primary.

The lawsuit, filed in New Mexico’s Supreme Court, names as a defendant the New Mexico secretary of state, Maggie Toulouse Oliver, who has publicly supported a move to open primaries.

In a written statement to POLITICO, Toulouse Oliver said, “My Office is in the process of reviewing the recently filed lawsuit regarding open primaries in New Mexico but I do support open primaries as they guarantee that every eligible voter has the same opportunity to make his or her voice heard.”

But New Mexico lawmakers have resisted proposals to establish an open primary in previous years, and the New Mexico Supreme Court in 2017 upheld the closed primary practice. Though the court that year considered a challenge based on a different part of the state constitution, it nevertheless cast doubt on the argument that independent voters are disenfranchised.

Registering with a party, the court ruled at the time, “is a reasonably modest burden that furthers the State’s interest in securing the purity of elections and efficiently administering them.”

In its current lawsuit, Open Primaries argues closed primaries constitute an unconstitutional donation to a private entity.

“New Mexico’s closed primary elections are exclusionary and held for the benefit of major political parties, which are purely private entities,” the lawsuit states. “Even though the primary election is closed and exclusionary, primary elections are paid for by public funds and New Mexico taxpayers, while the major political parties reap the benefits.”

New Mexico is one of nine closed-primary states, while another seven states allow parties to determine whether unaffiliated voters may participate in their nominating contests, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.

Twenty-eight states currently hold fully open primary elections or primaries in which unaffiliated voters may participate in any primary they choose, according to the NCSL.

“What we hope to bring with this case is renewed attention on how our primary election system in this country, which is often times run for the benefit of private organizations, has been publicly subsidized for years at the expense of the public,” said Jeremy Gruber, senior vice president at Open Primaries. “If the parties are allowed to be gatekeepers and decide who can and can’t participate, then these are not public elections for the purpose of public funding, and they should no longer be subsidized.”

PRESSLEY’S Instagram — MORSE makes 30 UNDER 30 list — What about 2022?

GOOD MORNING, MASSACHUSETTS.

Congress through PRESSLEY'S INSTAGRAM — If you want an inside look at freshman orientation underway for new lawmakers in Washington this week, just open Instagram. Through Congresswoman-elect Ayanna Pressley's Instagram account, we're getting first-person a look.

Story Continued Below

Pressley is part of a group of newly-elected lawmakers using social media in a completely different way than their predecessors. Their campaigns are over, the digital ads have been run and now the test is connecting with constituents as effectively as they connected with voters.

If you're on Instagram, it probably felt like everyone you follow was voting, from sticker selfies to "PLEASE VOTE!!!" posts leading up to Nov. 6. That was kind of true — 2.7 million people voted in Massachusetts last week. That's the highest midterm total ever for the state. And now, if you're following Pressley, you probably feel in the loop on what's going on at the orientation for new members of Congress.

On Monday, Pressley posted a candid photo with the caption, "Good morning, Washington." It has more than 16,500 likes and 337 comments. On her Instagram story, where temporary photos and videos last for 24 hours, there was a shot of her leaning in for a selfie with newly elected Congresswomen Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota and Rashida Tlaib of Michigan with the hashtag #NMO2018.

In another photo captioned "just a few freshman orientation essentials" she's got a to-go cup from Hill favorite Compass Coffee, a "bring your own chair" pin, an "indivisible" pen and a notebook arranged neatly on the table with a "Washington, D.C." location tag.

Click over to Ocasio-Cortez's profile and you'll find a photo of the four newly-elected congresswomen with the caption "Squad" and a video of them walking down the hallway together. The Cut summed up their Instagram posts in this headline : "Your Cool New Congresswomen Are Already Hanging Out." I'm interested to see how these new lawmakers use social media to communicate with constituents and reporters throughout the next Congress.

MORSE makes 30 UNDER 30 — Holyoke Mayor Alex Morse landed on the Forbes 30 Under 30 list yesterday. First elected as Holyoke's youngest and first openly gay mayor in 2011 at age 22, today he ranks among the city's longest-serving mayors. And now, at age 29, he's the city's first mayor to make it into the roundup of influential millennials, too.

"There were a lot of assumptions that I'd be mayor for a short period of time and then quickly move on, and I think now being in my fourth term I've demonstrated a long term commitment to the city," Morse told me. "I think it takes a while to make progress on really big issues in an urban community like Holyoke, and that's why I ran in the first place."

Morse said being named to the 30 Under 30 list is a "consequence of doing good work" in the city, and points to downtown revitalization, housing, transit-oriented development, a drop in crime and a rise in high school graduation rates as some of his achievements after seven years as mayor. Up next, he says, is Holyoke's position in the marijuana industry.

And as for running for higher office in the future, perhaps governor in four years, Morse says "it's way too early to think about it." The Holyoke mayor was named as a potential 2022 candidate in a Boston Globe story Tuesday afternoon about some very, very early speculation. "I don't know what the future holds. I see a future in public service, potentially in a different capacity one day, but for now I love what I do here in Holyoke," Morse said.

Christie ally up for federal judgeship is grilled over Christie scandals

Good Wednesday morning!

The Senate Judiciary Committee hearing for former Christie administration lawyer Paul Matey to become a 3rd Circuit judge gave us a small taste of what a confirmation hearing would be like for Christie if Trump nominates him for attorney general.

Story Continued Below

Two Democratic senators — Pat Leahy of Vermont and Mazie Hirono of Hawaii — brought up so many Christie administration and U.S. Attorney’s Office scandals that I had even forgotten about some of them. You can read my story about it here .

It’s also interesting that Sen. Cory Booker, who sites on the committee, avoided questioning Matey on Christie administration scandals, leaving it entirely up to his Democratic colleagues (the only Republican at the hearing was committee Chairman Chuck Grassley). Booker just focused on the poor safety record of University Hospital in Newark, where Matey until recently served as a legal executive.

I don’t know if Booker’s going to say ‘Aye Matey!’ if and when the nomination comes up for a vote. But if Christie comes before the same committee for his coveted cabinet post, Booker may have a harder time avoiding asking him pointed questions. Even if he does, he’s going to have to cast a vote on the nomination — and it will be very politically difficult for him to cast a yes vote.

AMAZON arrives in Queens — BLOOMBERG’S 2020 timeline — CUOMO whips votes for PELOSI Presented by Airbnb

The news that Amazon plans to build a new headquarters in Long Island City along the banks of the East River, in exchange for roughly $3 billion in city and state tax incentives, is leading the front pages of all our major papers this morning.

But the deal itself — the way it came together, the way the state’s two top Democrats, Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, negotiated it, and the way they rolled it out to the world yesterday — emblematized a key feature of de Blasio’s mayoralty: the often yawning chasm between his rhetoric and his actions.

The deal came together despite concerns from de Blasio’s progressive allies, and despite his previous concern that behemoths like Amazon could destroy local stores. “If you’re like me and you love your local neighborhood stores — your bakeries, your café, your clothing stores, all these things — then you need to spend your money there and not at Starbucks and not at other alternative places," de Blasio said last year.

Yesterday, he had something different to say.

“Amazon was going to have a second headquarters, and better it is us,” de Blasio said. "Better that a lot of that money ... will help us support small business and support neighborhoods. I feel really, really good about that."

And the unabashedly pro-union mayor expects the best from the city's new tenants: “As to Amazon’s much-criticized treatment of its lower-wage workers, de Blasio was optimistic that after imbibing New York City’s special brew of union-friendliness, Amazon would change its ways,” Dana and Gloria wrote yesterday.

“I would start by saying that I am happy Amazon will benefit from being in an environment that is pro-union and will start to see why this union town works so well,” de Blasio said.

De Blasio and Cuomo agreed to make a secret end run around the City Council’s sometimes cumbersome city planning process, to allay Amazon’s concerns that local officials or City Council members could veto the project.

“You have a democratically elected mayor and a democratically elected governor saying we had an unprecedented opportunity to add to the number of jobs in this city,” de Blasio said, explaining his decision to simply bypass the city’s typical process for building major projects. “And we were not going to let that slip through our hands.”

Almost three years ago, de Blasio signed a new law to cut noisy helicopter tourism traffic in the city in half, calling it "a major quality of life issue." But the deal to land the Amazon headquarters includes a concession to help the company, headed by the country's richest man, build its own helipad. The deal would allow 120 helicopter landings a year, roughly one every three days.

Before the selection was announced, local elected officials wondered what Amazon would do for the surrounding community, home to the Queensbridge Houses — the nation’s largest housing project and part of NYCHA, the crumbling home to more than 400,000 city residents. In the end, the stated terms of the deal include requirements that the trillion-dollar company provide some job training for Queensbridge residents, but do nothing to guarantee that those residents, many of whom are living at or below the poverty line, would fill any of the good-paying jobs the new headquarters will provide.

De Blasio, who once campaigned on the idea of ending “the tale of two cities,” just marveled at the contrast:

"One of the biggest companies on earth next to the biggest public housing development in the United States — the synergy is going to be extraordinary," he said.
